A  metre mast had been erected across from the house, intruding on one of the area#s most beautul views across Loch Fyne.#Mr MacDougall says neither he nor his neighbours were consulted beforehand.The Minard mast is one of around  installed in Argyll and Bute by contractor Arqiva on behalf of main contractor Smart DCC. The masts provide a link between smart meters installed in homes and the energy companies in a bid to improve energy use efficiency.An Arqiva spokesperson said: #The wireless network for smart metering uses existing infrastructure where possible, but some new masts need to be built to ensure virtually all energy consumers and businesses in Scotland will reap the benefits.#Whenever new masts are needed, we adhere to the full planning process.#Planning is controlled by the local authority and an Argyll and Bute Council spokesperson said: #The contractor Arqiva, as an electronic communications code operator, will use permitted development rights set out under Class  of Part  of Schedule  of the Town and Country Planning Order , as amended.#In some cases, as at Minard, the installation of apparatus will not trigger a specic requirement for planning permission.#There are no buildings within  metres of the development so, as per national guidelines, there is no requirement for neighbour notication.#The community council was informed of the proposed development in December  and, after discussion and a site meeting, members agreed that as this was a government initiative and the structure was of a small scale it had no objections to the application.West Loch Fyne Community Council convener Fred Bruce explained: #No comments were received by the community council from any Minard residents. It was our understanding all parties near the proposed site would receive statutory notication from the local authority. As no comments were made to the community council we made no adverse comment to planning re same.#He added: #Having visited the site we do not see there is any serious visual impact on the area. title: shop to ship plan to help island businesses stay afloat
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA #shop to ship# initiative has been launched to help shore-based businesses get goods to tourists onboard visiting vessels.Following the pandemic, the idea aims to help small businesses in remote areas and islands to carry on trading with visitors arriving by sea, while also respecting the concerns of communities about those stepping ashore.It aims to promote the advanced order and purchase of local seafood, fresh food, arts and crafts, with arrangements made between the business and visitor for the safe drop off and collection from quays, ports and harbours.The idea being that #marine tourists# use a dedicated website to find in advance about shore-based food and craft producers, and then make arrangements.The move hopes to help in the economic recovery of remote rural and island destinations which have been hard hit by the lockdown and rely on visitors.Sail Scotland, a membership group for the marine tourism industry, is behind the idea.Its web-based portal will allow businesses to promote beer, wines and spirits, local seafood, fresh foods, meats, bakery, dairy, takeaways, groceries, household items and arts, and crafts to customers arriving by sea.Alan Rankin, chief executive of Sail Scotland, said: #A key element of the world-class Scottish sailing experience is the world-class food and drink available through local shore-side businesses. This pilot initiative is aimed to enhance the sailing experience and offer vital sales to local coastal and island businesses.#Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing said: #It also enables inidual businesses and their host communities to be recognised as welcoming destinations, with the processes tailored precisely to local circumstances and built in from the beginning.#The further easing of lockdown allows yachts and boats to visit remote areas and islands.#Safe Sailing# guidelines have been published by Sail Scotland which asks visiting yachts to #Respect the Destination# by planning ahead, making a considered arrival and thinking local.Sail Scotland said no two destinations are the same, so the  aims to connect the producer and the consumer as easily as possible in a way that suits local wishes.Fiona Richmond, head of regional food at Scotland Food and Drink, said: #With restrictions beginning to unwind and businesses seeking to find new ways of working, it’s great to see innovative initiatives like the Shop to Ship marketplace, which provides a fantastic digital  for local businesses to reach new customers.#The Shop to Ship campaign will be promoted widely by Sail Scotland, Scotland Food and Drink and a range of others.The  is available  for businesses to register at https:www.sailscotland registration. It includes free associate membership of Sail Scotland.Respect The Destination guidelines

title: new island housing stifled by red tape
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsNew house building on islands and in rural areas is being stymied by red tape and high costs, according to a long-standing local developer.Kenny MacLeod, director of MacLeod Construction Ltd, Kilmory, said a lack of affordable infrastructure on the islands and in rural areas #  from roads to water and electricity and fibre-optics # made some housing projects dficult and unaffordable.It prevents growth on the islands and in rural communities # contributing to younger people moving away, he says.Mr MacLeod, of the Argyll-based construction firm and timber kit manufacturer, has  years’ experience of building new homes across Argyll and beyond # including developments in Oban and on islands such as Islay and Tiree.The need by regulatory authorities to impose ever higher national specications on local developments also proved more dficult and costly for rural areas, he said.Mr MacLeod explained: #My company is building  houses on the island of Jura.#The only public road on the island, from which access will be taken to the site, is single lane.#The internal road system planned for  affordable homes is required to be designed to city standards which is .-metre wide with two-metre pavements.#If development specications could be revised, the savings made would fund additional houses within the footprint of a site.#He said remote rural locations are more expensive to service because housing developments are on a smaller scale.MacLeod#s employs around  people directly and provides work to around -sub-contractors. It has made representations to the Scottish Government about a range of issues.The family-run company emphasised that the comments should not be seen as criticism of Argyll and Bute Council. Instead, they were directed at some national policies and how they impacted on rural development.Argyll and Bute Council had been #more than helpful# to local businesses in the recovery from lockdown, the company added.Mr MacLeod also suggested Scottish Water should be encouraged to allow small developments to be served by inidual septic tanks or bio-discs.In addition, the provision of water and electricity to remote rural locations should be subsidised by the Scottish Government, he added, which would help make projects more affordable.Furthermore, the cost of #impact studies,# should not fall on the developer, he said.Another issue was the requirement of registered social landlords that housing is built to extremely high specications, he said.Mr MacLeod said: #That high standard does, of course, ensure that the houses are well insulated and easily maintained. The standard, however, drives costs up dramatically and can make small, rural developments unaffordable.Careful planning of the specication could reduce building costs but still produce warm, highly insulated and comfortable homes.#While there is Scottish Government funding for affordable housing and funding through the Highlands and Islands Enterprise Agency for workshop units, there is no funding for #combined# units which incorporate a home and a workspace.This would allow young entrepreneurs to acquire a starter home or a home worker to relocate.Argyll and Bute Council has one of the highest approval rates for new planning applications in Scotland.It said: #Masterplans are rarely implemented in Argyll and Bute but they are used occasionally to enable the partial development of larger areas of land.#Infrastructure costs make up a signicant proportion of the cost of new build housing particularly in smaller scale developments.#

title: absolutely-vital-shop-local-save-high-streets
story: The Scotland Loves Local campaign has launched across the country to encourage Scots to go back to their roots, think local first and support their local high streets safely and in line with public healthguidelines.The Coronaviruspandemic has hit high streets and local businesses hard - now is the time to support them to get back on their feet. Whether you need a book, a pint of milk, a night out and a meal, a bedside table or some garden furniture.by Phil Prentice,Chief Officer, Scotlandrsquos Towns PartnershipThink local first. Itrsquos a simple but powerful plea - one which really could have a tremendous influence on Scotlandrsquos economic fightback from coronavirus.Town centres have a critical role to play in the countryrsquos safe recovery from the pandemic. Businesses in them stand ready to be on the frontline of a triumphant comeback, but they need your help to secure success.By taking care about public health and thinking local first, we can rebuild our economyfrom its grassroots, ensuring our home communities are fantastic and vibrant hubs for retail and leisure.Thatrsquos why we at Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnerships, in association with the Scottish Government, have launched the ScotlandLoves Local campaign, to champion the tremendous businesses - whether a pub, cafe, tailor, butcher or a grocery shop - which really are the leblood of our economy.I am sure that one of the things which Covid- has taught us is the importance of localism and our towns are an important part of that. Indeed, we owe much of the innovation, invention and culture that Scotland is renowned for to our towns.The outbreak has, of course, caused signicant challenges for our town centres, high streets and local businesses. They have lost out to the large internet retail giants because they had to close to keep us safe. In fact, even despite these challenges, many of them have gone to enormous s to support the most vulnerable people and have been at the heart of some fantastic community responses.These actions have served to highlight that our high streets arenrsquot just a series of buildings where things are bought and sold. The people who run local businesses are our family, friends and neighbours.Challenges facing our towns and high streets are nothing new. Wersquove been talking about what our towns and high streets look like in the future for many years, but the unprecedented challenge of Covid- is the reckoning that must spur us into action.Looking to our future, with new thinking and innovation, the opportunities are endless ndash whether in redesigning our high streets to be carbon neutral, embracing a digital first approach or ing our towns to community hubs and social spaces.But, here and now, getting our high streets back on their feet in the safest possible way is pivotal. In so many ways, our high streets have always been there for us. Now is the time for us to be there for them.,params: .pushScotland Loves Local is about encouraging all of us to think local while following all social distancing, face covering and other public health guidelines, whether yoursquore looking for a book, pint of milk, night out and a meal, a bedside table or some garden furniture.This isnrsquot just about keeping shop units occupied, itrsquos bigger than that. Itrsquos about supporting the very fabric of our society and community.With support from the Scottish Government through the Towns and BusinessImprovement Districts Resilience and Recovery Fund, communities across the country are already pulling together to weather this storm.My plea to you is to stick with us: Live local, shop local, love local. The dference you can make is great.

title: scotlands-school-return-child-psychologist-reveals-three-top-tips
story: A child psychologist has revealed their top tops on how to help children handle theto school in Scotland ndash amid fears they could be faced with ldquoemotional trauma.Schools across the country are set to open from August , with scientic advice published by the Scottish Government last week saying pupils should not have to physically distance when they go back.Face coverings should not generally be needed but staff should stay two metres away from children and other staff where possible.What concerns are being raised Despite the welcome , a leading teaching union has warned ofthe emotional trauma for children ing to school after a prolonged period off, and said a phasedwould be lsquovitalrsquo for their wellbeing.Alison Murphy, Secretary of the Edinburgh Educational Institute of Scotland local association, said: ldquoChildren will need to be run through lsquoThis is where you wash your handsrsquo, lsquoThis is your bit of the playgroundrsquo, lsquoThis is how the one-way system worksrsquo and so on.ldquoYou wonrsquot be able to do that per cent of pupils are in the building on the first day.ldquoIt would be chaos - it wouldnrsquot be safe.ldquoAnd therersquos the emotional trauma - theyrsquove been away from school for months.ldquoAn adult who had been off work for four months would be entitled to a phasedand for good reasons.Schools have been closed as a result of the virusWhat advice is being given The online tutoring service MyTutorhas enlisted the advice ofDr. Shreena Ghelani ndash a senior clinical psychologist ndash about how to handle theto school.Here are her three tips:Managing worry and anxietyIf you know your child might struggle with going back to school, try developing a mental toolbox of things they can do when they are worried at school.This might include a song to sing to themselves, visualising a calm place, practising breathing techniques and identying safe staff they can tellthey begin to feel nervous during the day.Speak to your children about the impact of CoronavirusLet children know that it is likely that other families may have been impacted by the virus,whether thatrsquos keyworking parents working hard, or family bereavements.Encourage your child to be patient and kindto other children.Let you child know what they might still be expected to do ndash not hug friends, wash their hands more often, or not share toys.Donrsquot rush to get back to normal too quicklyWhen school restarts in your area, you may find that children are more tired than usual by the extra demands and sensory stimulation placed on them.Ease them back in to their routine gently and allow enough space and time in a new schedule for any hiccups so that yoursquore not having to manage too many demands.When the time comes, yoursquoll find yoursquoll feel less stressedyou know there will be bumps in the road.You can find more tips and online tutoring at MyTutor.

title: hidden-disability-face-mask-exemptions-card----can-get-one
story: FACE coverings became mandatory in Scotlands shopson July  - but not everyone has to wear them.First Minister Nicola Sturgeonhas remindedthe public that many people have disabilities which consistently."Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who title: borders-athlete-sammi-kinghorn-appears-bbcs-one-show
story: SAMMI Kinghorn appeared in a BBC television programme this week.The wheelchair racer, from the Borders, featured in anepisode of The One Showwhich aired on July .Kinghorn, who was expecting to be competing in the Tokyo  Paralympics, told viewers how she felt when she learned the prestigious event was being postponed due to coronavirus.She said: ldquoWhen I first heard Tokyo was going to be delayed, it was quite heartbreaking because I felt really strong and I felt really fast.ldquoBut now I feel quite positive about knowing that Irsquove got another year to get stronger.Asked about her goals, she said: ldquoIrsquom aiming for gold because therersquos no point being therethatrsquos not what Irsquom aiming for.The -year-oldrsquos achievements include winning gold medals for m and m at the London  world championships, and reaching three finals at the  Paralympics in Rio .She is one of the fastest British wheelchair athletes ever.Her entry into the world of elite sports came following an injury on her familyrsquos farm in .The One Showepisode, hosted by Alex Jones and Rylan Clark Neal, featured guests including journalist and author Caitlin Moran and chef Monica Galetti.

title: young-borders-residents-set-fashion-businesses
story: YOUNG entrepreneurs from across the Borders are emerging after lockdown.With studies predicting a steep rise in youth unemployment this year, some young people are taking matters into their own hands.Trystan Andrews, Arran Paterson and Callum Hastings - a group of teenagers from Earlston and Lauder - recently launched a clothing business for outdoor wear.Describing bothybothy, the group said: ldquoWe always view bothy trips as a method of escape and re-setting our minds.ldquoWe were thankful for this discovery and thought it would be cruel not to share our passion for this magnicent aspect of le.ldquoOur comfortable clothes will remind you that there is always an option to escape the pressure of the modern world.ldquoThe name bothybothy was chosen as it is how we live our le. Simply waiting for the opportunity for another bothy trip.Currently, the company sells three T-shirt designs and one jumper design, with the potential for a wider range in the future.Bothybothy came to le after Callum combined his savings with those of Trystan and Arran, both . Callum turns  today .When the Border asked the group to identy the best thing about running their own business, they replied: ldquoWe can do work when we choose to and the only rush is our own desire to get the products onto the market and start selling.ldquoWe donrsquot need to report to anyone above us because we are all equals in this venture and make every decision as a group.ldquoWe would actively encourage other young people to start their own business.ldquoOur advice is to spend time researching all aspects thoroughly before ing straight in.Another fashion-minded Borderer is Ellen McFadzen, a -year-old from Selkirk.She had tohome from France when COVID- put a stop to her travel plans in March.However, she has used her spare time to pursue her love of fashion - and she now owns her own business.LoveNelle offers a made-to-measure range as well as bespoke garments. Ellen makes her own patterns, orders the fabrics, and markets the products.ldquoIrsquom quite a hands-on person who wants to do everything myself, said Ellen. ldquoBut my advice to young entrepreneurs is: lsquoDonrsquot be afraid to ask for helprsquo.ldquoI went into this not knowing how I could turn what I loved doing into a business but here I am.Ellen was taught to sew by her granny and her hobby progressed during lockdown as she documented her style online for her friends and family.They encouraged her to pursue her sewing dream and turn her needle skills into a business.Ellen told the Border : ldquoI love clothes that are more flamboyant than those you would traditionally find in stores.ldquoI want to break through fast fashion and throw-away culture by helping people embrace their quirks and not strive to follow each trend.ldquoI also want to make clothes that fit people without the stress of meeting standard shop sizes.If any more young Borderers have recently launched their own business, please let us know by contacting: editorial@bordertelegraph

title: amazon-prime-day-2020-postponed-happen
story: Amazon Prime Day is a huge online shopping event which seesusers of the online servicebag themselves a range of deals and bargains.However, this year the event isnrsquot going ahead as planned and instead has been postponed, due to the coronavirus crisis.This is everything you need to know about the  event - including when it might be happening.What is Amazon Prime Day Amazon Prime Day is an annual online event that allows Amazon Prime members the opportunity to shop exclusive deals over the course of two days.Users are able to take advantage of limited time only lsquolightning dealsrsquo as well as other Prime Day deals across the site.You can sign up for a -day free trial with Amazon Prime, so you donrsquot need to be an existing user prior to Amazon Prime Day in order to bag some deals.When will Amazon Prime Day happen A spokesperson for Amazon said:ldquoOver the last five years, Prime Day has become a special celebration and time for Prime members to shop incredible deals for themselves and for friends and family - and itrsquos something we look forward to every year.ldquoThis year wersquoll be holding Prime Day later than usual, while ensuring the safety of our employees and supporting our customers and selling partners.The date of Amazon Prime Day in the UK is yet to be confirmed, but it has been revealed that the online shopping event will go ahead in India on August  and .The spokesperson said:ldquoMembers all around the world will experience Prime Day later this year. We look forward to sharing more details soon.When might Prime Day happen Tech site Tech Radar estimates that Prime Day could occur in October - an email to third party sellers suggested that the UK date would be postponed by three months.Tech Radar also explains that Amazon generally picks a Monday to start the deals, with Prime Day running through until Tuesday.If October is the month that Prime Day is set to take place, there are four possible Mondays to choose from:Monday, October, Monday,October, Monday,October, Monday,October, On the other hand, reports from the Wall Street Journal indicatethat September could be the launch month for UK Prime Day.At the end of the day, however, there is no way to know when Prime Day in the UK could kick off until Amazon itself announces it.

title: borders-beauty-salons-reopen---i-cried-relief
story: BEAUTY therapists get back to work todayas studios reopen after  weeks.Salon owners had an anxious wait as the Scottish Government considered what new safety guidelines ought to be introduced to minimise the risk of spreading coronavirus.But industry figures were delighted to learn that ndash unlike their counterparts over the border ndash they will be able to offer treatments on the face, so long as therapists stand to the side or back of the clientrsquos head."I was so relieved, I actually cried, said Alana Grant, owner of Borders Beauty Studio in Galashiels, adding: ldquoOver  per cent of our treatments are on the face.The business, which during lockdown relocated from Bank Street to Market Street, was concerned that similar restrictions to England would be imposed.Miss Grant said: "A number of our treatments are on the face, so we probably couldnt opennot allowed to provide these treatments."Every day I was checking the guidelines and speaking with other shop owners in the Borders and in Edinburgh.Masks, visors, aprons, gloves and perspex iders will be used at Borders Beauty Studio, with stations being deep-cleaned after use.And over and above the requested measures, Miss Grant and her team will be testing the temperatures of customers on arrival, using a contactless thermometer.Customers will be encouraged to use hand-washing and sanitising stations when entering and exiting the shop.Miss Grant told the Border she was pleased to have been able to furlough all her staff, meaning all have been retained ndash therapists and reception staff alike ndash as the studio reopens.Reflecting on her journey over recent months, Miss Grant said: "It was a very worrying time. In the first initial month we didnt know what was going to happen."Our waiting list is pages long, and having that when we were closed really helped us to know wed have an income when we reopened."Our first two weeks are fully booked, and the first couple of months well definitely have clients."Because were taking  minutes to clean between appointments, and have staggered appointments, we will lose some money. But anything is better than being closed."The studio has also prepared an explanatory video for customers before arrival, giving them a virtual walkthrough of what to expect when they visit in the coming weeks.Clients are shown the sanitising process, where they will store their belongings during appointments and the payment process."Customers will be able to relax because its a safe place," Miss Grant added."I know I feel anxious when in a new place and youre unsure of the rules."Beauty salons and other close-contact businesses are reopening as part of phase three of the Scottish Governmentrsquos route map out of lockdown.Salons were first told to close their doors in March.

title: comet-neowise-once-in-6800-years-chance-see-rare-comet-scotland-tonight
story: Stargazers are being urged to look to the sky tonight at a newly discovered comet which will not be coming back for another  years.The mountain-sized Neowise comet made its closest approach to the sun on July  and is now shining brightly in the night skies.Neowise survived a close encounter with the sun, and during its closest approach will be about  million miles away from the earth ndash but still visible to the human eye.Comet Neowise is visible to the naked eyeDr Robert Massey, from the Royal Astrological Society, said Neowise was last in the inner Solar System  years ago and it was not expected tofor another  years.He said: ldquoI would encourage everyone to take a lookthey can,they have clear skies, and get away from light pollutionthey can.How and when can I see the comet Comet Neowise reaches its closest point to the earth tomorrow morning around  minutes before sunrise - at around .am.One easy way to spot the comet is to look for the Big Dipper- which should be visible eastwards on a clear night with little light pollution.Neowise should be below the Big Dipper, about  degrees above the horizon.What has NASA said A Nasa spokesman said: ldquoA comet has suddenly become visible to the unaided eye.ldquoComet C  Fwas discovered in late March and brightened as it reached its closest approach to the sun, inside the orbit of Mercury, late last week.ldquoThe interplanetary iceberg survived solar heating, so far, and is now becoming closer to the Earth as it starts its long trek back to the outer Solar System."NASA also provided their own three tips to seeing Neowise:Find a spot away from city lights with an unobstructed view of the skyJust after sunset, look below the Big Dipper in the northwest skyIf you have them, bring binoculars or a small telescope to get the best views of this dazzling display

title: coronavirus-scotrail-offers-free-travel-unemployed----even-get-job
story: SCOTRAIL is offering jobseekers free travel to help them get back to work.The coronavirus pandemic has had a huge impact on jobs in Scotland, with figures in May suggesting the number of people claiming unemployment benefit has increased by .% - up about , to ,.The travel firm saysthat the cost of travelling to an interview can ldquooften be a barrier to ing to work ndash so launched a scheme to fast-track the process.The idea was launched in , but has recently been marketed againby ScotRailas a result of the coronavirus.What can jobseekers get Those eligible can get two freejourneys a month to attend an interview.They can also then get a free ScotRail travel ticket for the first month of theirto work.Jobseekers are also able to take advantage of the Jobcentre Plus Travel Discount Card - a UK Government initiative which allows those who are unemployed and claiming Jobseekerrsquos Allowance or Universal Credit to receive a % discount on selected rail tickets.If youre out of work, were offering two free tickets per month for travel to interviews - as well as a free one month ticket once you secure a job.mdash ScotRailJuly , Am I eligible for the scheme To be eligible for any of these offers, the customer must have been claiming Jobseekers Allowance or Universal Credit for - monthsor - months .How does it work Tickets for travel to interview:For jobseekers to obtain up to two freetickets per month to attend interviews, their local Job Centre issues them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a local station where staff will issue a ticket .One month ticket once employment secured:If the jobseeker secures employment and wishes to apply for a free monthrsquos ticket, their local Job Centre will issue them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a station where staff will issue a ticket .What does ScotRail say ScotRail Alliance Managing Director Alex Hynes said: ldquoFor people out of work, the cost of travelling to an interview can often be a barrier to ing to work.ldquoBy removing that barrier and providing help with the cost, we hope to be able to support people into work and grow Scotlandrsquos economy.ldquoThe support we offer to jobseekers is one of the ScotRail Alliancersquos best kept secrets ndash but I want as many people as possible to know about this opportunity.

title: coronavirus-poll-scots-support-another-lockdown-second-wave-occurs
story: MORE than three-quarters of people in Scotland would back another nationwide lockdown in the event of a second wave of coronavirus, a new poll suggests.In the study carried out by YouGov, % of people ldquostrongly support the idea of full measures being introduced in the event of a second wave, with a further % ldquosomewhat supportive of the idea.Meanwhile just under one in tenof Scots would ldquostrongly oppose the second lockdown, with another % ldquosomewhat opposing the idea.The remaining % of the responded as ldquodonrsquot know.The YouGov poll surveyed  adults.It comes as figures in Scotland revealed there had been no deaths of people who tested positive for the virus recorded in the past week ndash meaning the toll remains at  ndash and only one in the past  days.The First Minister described this as the ldquoincredible progress made since the country went into lockdown.In the last few weeks Scots have been able to enjoy more freedoms, including the reopening of pubs, restaurants and the tourism sector.Another YouGov poll of the same number of adults revealed that % of people in Scotland would not have a coronavirus vaccine when it became available.The vast majority ndash around %, said they would take the vaccine, with a further % responding as ldquodonrsquot know.

title: midge-repellents-top-tips-keep-scotlands-biting-beasties-bay
story: IT is a ferocious and much-feared beast, one that has long wreaked misery across Scotland, emerging at dusk ndash or dawn ndash to feast on human blood.The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Here we test some of the best midge-repelling lotions and potions:Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency:A dry oil spray.Smell:Baby talcum powder.Verdict:Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency:A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell:Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict:Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.,params: .pushIngredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency:A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell:Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict:A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency:A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell:Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict:An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: scotlands-schools-four-key-updates-parents-ahead-reopening
story: PARENTS across Scotland are eagerly anticipating confirmation that schools will go back full time next month.Primary and secondary schools across the country closed their doors back in March to all but a few children.But with coronavirus in Scotland being suppressed to very low levels, things are looking optimistic regarding ato the classroom.Yesterday, education secretary John Swinney provided an update on schools.Here are fourkey things we learned:Teachers:The Scottish Government yesterday announced pound million of funding to employ hundreds of teachers and support staff to help schools reopen.An extra pound million was also pledged to cover other health protection costs.The funding will equate to around  teachers and  support staff.But as Labourrsquos education spokesperson, Iain Gray, pointed out, that accounts for only half a new member of staff per school across Scotland.August   Councils and schools have been working to the August date for some time.But the Scottish Government will not formally announce the August date until July .The Scottish Government has repeatedly stressed that reducing the infection rate is crucial to the reopening of schools, with the First Minister earlier in the week suggesting no more lockdown changes will be made until pupils are back in the classroom.Mr Swinney stressed that in Scotland, the infection rate is ldquoreducing by  per cent each week, but a sudden surge in cases over the next few weeks could sht the Scottish Governmentrsquos confidence that it is safe to re-open schools.Some pupils may have to socially distanceSocial distancingMr Swinney gave parents some much-needed details about the social distancing guidance that schools will be asked to follow ndash but some questions still remain over how this will work in practice.While primary pupils will not have to socially distance when theyon August , all being well, secondary schools will be told to enforce physical distancing rules ldquowhere possible.Mr Swinney said this was due to the scientic advice on social distancing being ldquoless clear for older pupils.Meanwhile secondary schools will be asked to adjust the layout of classrooms and manage flows of people in and out of buildings ndash but with a catch.This social distancing rule in secondary schools will be ldquosubject always to this not reducing capacity within the school.Youth clubsAs well as earmarking pound million for school staff and pound million to help councils meet extra costs in reopening classrooms, pound million of previously announced money will be used to support youth work in connection with schools being reopened.Mr Swinney said this funding has been announced as the sector has ldquocontinued to support and engage children and young people through the pandemic, highlighting the use of digital technology to help mitigate the impact of the lockdown on young peoplersquos mental health.

title: staff-face-redundancy-borders-call-centre--
story: STAFF are facing redundancy at a Galashiels call centre.Sykes has engaged its Nether Road employees in a consultation over their jobs.A Border reader, who said they work at the call centre, told us: "It cant be helped but its devastating to be losing work at a horrible time."A spokesperson for Sykes said: "After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."Staff were told about the job losses around three weeks ago, according to the employee who contacted the Border .The employee - who we have granted anonymity - said staff were informed their contracts are coming to an end, with managers also affected."I feel pretty stressed, everyone is feeling the pressure and are worried what to do," the source said.They added: "Theres added stress of finding a job at a time with hardly any jobs available."Some people may be lucky and walk into a new job."Im looking for employment, hoping theres something to take on or Im going to have to seek help from the Job Centre."The source also revealed that the redundancy talks are having an impact on the mental health of some staff."Ive spoken to others and theyre all struggling - their mood is very low, the source said, adding: "People with houses, kids or mortgages are going to struggle.A Sykes spokesperson said: "Sykes is responsive to the needs of the market and our clients in a constantly changing business landscape."The decision to make such changes is never easy."After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."The Border has contacted the company to ask how many jobs will be lost.Have you been affected by redundancy talks in the Borders  Get in touch by emailing: editorial@bordertelegraph

title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: TODAY marks two weeks since face coverings became mandatory in shops across Scotland.So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government says that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:When applying or removing the covering, it is important that you wash sanitise your handsfirst and avoid touching your face.After EACH USE, you must wash the face covering at  degrees centigrade or dispose of it safely.Who is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:Children under fiveyears of age.Police constables or workers such as paramedics acting in the course of their duty.Staff such as drivers or checkout assistants who are physically separated, by means of, for example, screens, from passengers or customers.Shop workersthey maintain a two-metre distance from customers or members of the public.You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafeand protect others ##mdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:You have a health condition or you are disabled and a face covering would be inappropriate because it would cause dficulty, pain or severe distress or anxiety or because you cannot apply a covering and wear it in the proper manner safely and consistently.Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.You need to eat or drink.You are taking medication.You are communicating with someone  who relies on lip reading.A relevant person, such as a police officer, asks you to remove your face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: IF you are looking for a staycation that stokes the imagination, Scotland has no shortage of unusual and quirky gems.With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit stayatalighthouseCalgary, MullNot to be confused with the skyscraper-filled city in Alberta, this little corner of Mull is a delight.A byre, hayloft and dovecote are among the self-catering properties available at Calgary, each with its own distinctive character. Calgary also has an excellent cafe, art gallery and a woodland sculpture walk.Therersquos a beach within strolling distance where Robinrsquos Boat sells Isle of Mull ice cream. Sea eagles, otters and basking sharks can all be seen nearby.,params: .pushPrices start from pound for a seven-night stay. Call   or visit calgaryThe Scriptorium Apartments at St Benedictrsquos Abbey, Fort AugustusThe Scriptorium ndash the once secret writing room of the monastery ndash has two one-bedroom apartments with vaulted ceilings, gothic archways and stained-glass windows. Therersquos plenty to do in the grounds and gardens, be it tennis, badminton, croquet or giant chess. The former Monksrsquo Refectory has been converted into a Club Lounge and a chapel refurbished to incorporate a heated pool, sauna and steam room.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit parrandierThe Brochs of Coigach, near Achiltibuie, UllapoolBrochs are an ancient dwelling found only in Scotland, dating back to BC. Gille Buidhersquos Broch and Scalrsquos Broch are a bit younger than thatand beautully enchanting structures.If you love upcycling, they will impress, built using stones from old, crumbling walls on nearby land and timber recovered from a dilapidated Victorian pier. Oil paintings by John Bellany hang on the walls, alongside display cabinets filled with weird and wonderful objects.Prices from pound per night. Call   or visit thebrochsThe Four Sisters Boatel, EdinburghTucked away in the heart of the Scottish capital, this houseboat is permanently moored at the Lochrin Basin on the Union Canal ndash the eastern terminus for the -mile stretch of water that comes all the way from Falkirk. Sleeping up to six adults and two children, it is an ideal base to explore Edinburgh, with Bruntsfield and the West End, as well as the Old and New Towns, all just a stonersquos throw away.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit thefoursistersThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireTalk about enjoying the great outdoors in style. Stay in a sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill.A rustic, wooden seed store with roots back to the s serves as the kitchen, dining and sitting room. There are games, books, a record player and a memorable barbecue spot. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages, as well as running residential courses in crafts and wild food.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottages

title: author-chris-lloyd-were-surrounded-magic
story: CHILDRENrsquoS author Chris Lloyd says lockdown makes it feel like ldquosomeone has switched the gravity off.The Kent-based non-fiction writer spoke to the Border ahead of his turn at the virtual version of the Borders Book Festival, the physical event having been cancelled due to coronavirus.When not grappling with zero-gravity, Lloyd, , has spent the last  years writing books for children, inspired by nature and the history of the world beyond humans.Discussing his  release, Humanimal, Lloyd said: "Children are born with an instinct, an intuition that all living things are connected and that theyre part of an ecosystem."This is the way we are naturally but society and culture tend to beat that out of us ndash they tell us were more intelligent."The point of the book is to try to preserve, for children, this reality of interconnectivity, and to give them some protection to whats happened to us adults over the years.ldquoWhich is the inevitable feeling that we are what matters and that everything  is there to serve us or for us to use or exploit."We cant continue with that mindset as a species and survive."As this is the message he is keen to share, Humanimaland Lloyds other works are not designed to act as an "A to Z encyclopaedia" of information, but rather tell the planets natural history away from the impact of humanity."All my books are meant for adults as well as children," said Lloyd. ldquoTheyre illustrated and designed in a way that makes adults want to buy them for children and I hope children want to share them with adults."Its a book, its a story, its something to be discussed, its something to be read out loud, its something to be looked at together.ldquoIts not a book and a child, its really something to open doors as much as anything ."And Lloyd believes, as much magic as there is in fiction, non-fiction ndash and the content that inspires it ndash can hold just as much whimsy.He said: "For me non-fiction has always been the more magical part of literature. There are a lot of young people for whom the real world is more amazing than anything you could make up."Again, thats another thing were born with that gets beaten out of us, and we start using the word ordinary ndash and theres nothing ordinary."Were surrounded by magic. You think Harry Potters magic  Just look around you."That curiosity is our biggest asset because thats how we learn to adapt, thats how we learn to survive, thats how we learn to cope with the world around us as it changes."Lloyd, who previously worked as a Sunday Timesjournalist, was inspired to begin a career as a childrens author after seeing the joy his children experienced when they learnt new things during their years in home-schooling.Particularly that of one of his daughters who was astonished to learn all about Antarctica ndash home of her then favourite animal, the penguin."I believe fundamentally, especially now having done thousands of talks in schools and festivals over the last  years, that humans generally reach peak curiosity at the age of nine or ," Lloyd said."Then things start to get in the way, like puberty and your friendship groups change and going from primary to secondary school."But at the age of nine or  youve got that purity of curiosity where youre old enough to know that you have an identity and youre curious enough to want to know where you fit in."Theres nothing you cant talk to a nine or -year-old about ndash provided you dont patronise them, provided you dont have an expectation of them that they cant meet."If you can meet them as fellow kindred spirits on this rock travelling around the sun, in this incredible galaxy, and here we are, face to face, learning about it and discovering things together, then there is nothing more inspiring than engaging with a nine or -year-old."Chris Lloyds Humanimalbook event will be broadcast on Sunday, July  at am as part of the festivals Family Series, and will include a discussion portion after a short presentation by Lloyd.The event is suitable for families with children aged seven and over.

title: sykes-redundancies-john-lamont-seeks-meeting-bosses
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont is seeking an ldquourgent meeting with call centre bosses following news of redundancies in Galashiels.Sykes employees face losing their jobs at Nether Road.Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, described the looming redundancies as ldquodevastating.He said: ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.A Sykes spokespersontold the Border on July  that staff are being consulted about job losses.But some employees later approached this newspaper to say every worker has been told their last day will be at the end of August, when the entire call centre will close.Sykes has been contacted for further comment.Mr Lamont said: ldquoThe reports of these redundancies at the Sykes call centre is devastating.ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.ldquoSykes are a big employer in the Borders so these job losses will add further challenges for our local economy as it begins to recover from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoI am seeking an urgent meeting with the management team to see what support can be provided.ldquoFor anybody who is worried about their job and is looking for advice, I would encourage them to contact me and I will do my best to assist.

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-august-announced
story: DAVID Baldacci, Sara Pascoe and Sebastian Barry are among the stars appearing at the online Borders Book Festival in August.The online edition of the festival, which launched on July , offers free-to-view talks every week.The line-up for August has now been unveiled, with festival director Alistair Moffat hailing a ldquodynamic schedule.Mr Moffat said: ldquoWersquove been delighted with the positive response wersquove received since the virtual festival launched this month and are excited to reveal a lively and eclectic line-up for August.Former Love Islandcontestant Camilla Thurlow is among the guests due to appear.Others include crime writer Val McDermid, broadcaster Sally Magnusson and childrenrsquos author Alan Windram ndash who is from Galashiels.This is the full line-up for AugustSunday, August am: Alan Windram will be launching the latest title from his award-winning picture book series One Button Bennypm: Broadcaster and novelist Sally Magnusson on myth, immortality and the role of women in society with festival director Alistair Moffatpm: US bestselling thriller writer David Baldacci talks to Lee Randall about his latest novel A Minute to MidnightSunday, August am: Hilarious adventures from Wigglesbottom Primary with Pamela Butchartpm: Dutch historian Rutger Bregman presents a new view on human naturepm: Award-winning novelist Sebastian Barry on his latest novel A Thousand MoonsSunday, August am: Eilidh Muldoon will show young viewers how to draw a very sleepy owl in this launch event for Snooze.pm: Environmental campaigner Jonathon Porritt presents a compelling blueprint for post-COVID - recoverypm: Former Bishop of Edinburgh, and bestselling author Richard Holloway helping us to make sense of the world with writer and broadcaster Sally MagnussonThursday, August pm: The riotously funny comedian Sara Pascoe will be joining the festival with an exclusive midweek special event on modern masculinity and sexual economicsSunday rd Augustam: Fun facts and drawing tips from master cartoonist Gary Northfield, the creator of the hilarious Julius Zebra bookspm: How to change the world with young activist and entrepreneur Jeremiah Emmanuelpm: Unrivalled queen of crime Val McDermid on her latest heart-pounding thriller Still LeSunday, August am: Much-loved Sir Charlie Stinky Socks author, Kristina Stephensonpm: Reflections on celebrity culture and mental health with Camilla Thurlow and her inspirational new memoir Not The Typepm: Dr Amir Khan, from Channel rsquos Behind Closed Doors, talks about his brand-new book The Doctor Will See You Now and tells us how he helped lead one of the busiest GP surgeries in the country through the unprecedented trials of the COVID pandemic.All events from the July programme are still available to view for free at any time from the festival website www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: borders-football-fans-tell-stories-new-book
story: FOOTBALL fans from Galashiels are featured in new book examining rivalries from around the world.Us and Them: New Journeys in Football Rivalry is published by anti-sectarian charity Nil By Mouth.As well as including accounts from Bilbao, China and Kosovo, the book tells the stories of Tam Cass and Johnny Sweeney, who watched their teams compete in the tragic Ibrox Stadium Disaster fixture of  where  fans lost their lives.The chapter lsquoCity Rivalsrsquo was written by Nil by Mouth director Dave Scott, who lives in the Borders.He said: ldquoFootball rivalry, especially when it comes to the lsquoOld Firmrsquo, is a cocktail of pride, passion, pantomime and poison.ldquoIt would be easy to focus on the negatives but we choose to look at some interesting stories of friendship across the ide, both on and off the pitch, examining the relationship between [Celticrsquos] Billy McNeill and [Rangers player] John Greig as well as allowing supporters the opportunity to tell their own stories.ldquoTam and Johnnyrsquos story is an extremely powerful one as it shows how they could easily set aside sporting rivalry when faced which much deeper human experiences.Writers who have contributed to the book include Daniel Gray and Andrew Downie.Visit nilbymouth.org for more information.

title: border
story: AN MSP is calling for Borderers to be mindful of those who cannot wear face coverings for medical reasons.The masks became mandatory in shops and on public transport several weeks ago.But there are exemptions, such as people with a health condition or living with a disability.And Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton is encouraging retailers, shopkeepers and the general public to be considerate and to adhere to the two-metre social distancing rule when near people without a covering.She said: ldquoWe need to all look out for each other at this dficult time.ldquoWearing face coverings in shops reduces the risk of transmission but we must be mindful that not everyone can wear one.ldquoSome people with medical conditions or disabilities are unable to wear face coverings, and we must recognise that they will require more personal space when moving around shops.ldquoThat is why, regardless of face coverings, to remain at a safe distance from people in shops and enclosed spaces."The British Lung Foundation has produced a downloadable graphic that people can show on their phones to explain why they arenrsquot wearing a face covering.The card aims to inform staff when entering shops and supermarkets, and on public transport.Sarah MacFadyen, head of policy at Asthma UK and the British Lung Foundation, said: ldquoItrsquos important to wear a face covering where advised not only to protect yourself but others around you, who could be more vulnerable to COVID-."However, we need a greater awareness that there are exemptions from the rules on face coverings, and this includes people with severe respiratory conditions."Most people will be able to wear a face covering with no problem, but some people find that wearing a mask makes them feel like they canrsquot breathe.Visit www.blf.org.uk to download the graphic.

title: msps-call-signs-display-virus-advice-cross-border-routes
story: THREE MSPs have written to transport bosses in a bid to get the latest COVID- advice displayed on electronic road signs in the Borders.Last week, Christine Grahame and fellow SNP politicians Emma Harper and Joan McAlpine sent as joint letter to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England.They want the information boards on cross-border routes to highlight the dferences in coronavirus restrictions.The MSPs said some of their constituents were "concerned" that visitors coming into the region from other parts of the UK were unfamiliar with the dferences in the COVID- rules.And that the confusion had even caused "animosity" with local businesses and residents.Christine Grahame, MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said: "While I welcome people coming to visit the Borders ndash world-renowned for its history and outstanding scenery ndash we want to ensure that people enjoy the area safely and understand that in Scotland we have our own approach to easing the COVID- restrictions, which dfers from the approach taken by other parts of the UK."To this end, we have jointly written to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England to request that electronic road signage on cross-border routes between the two nations reflect the dferences in COVID- restrictions.ldquoScotland has made excellent progress towards stopping the spread of COVID-, and now as we are starting to see more of our tourism, leisure and hospitality businesses open, we want to ensure this good progress continues while keeping local communities safe.ldquoOne way to inform people is by ensuring that everyone is aware of the measures which are in place in Scotland, as they head north, and England as they head south, which we encourage everyone to follow.ldquoWe look forward to hearing back from both Transport Scotland and Highways England soon.

title: big-changes-furlough-scheme-august-1----need-know
story: MAJOR changes to the furlough scheme are to come this week.Employers across the UK have until Friday to submit claims for furloughed staff for periods ending on or before June .The UK Government introduced new rules at the start of the month, allowing furloughed employees back to work for any amount of time or sht pattern.Employers would pay the wages for those days, with the UK Government still pay the % grant ndash up to a cap of pound per month ndash on the days not worked.But from Saturday, August , more major changes are to come into effect.What are the changes From Saturday, the level of grant will be reduced each month until the scheme ends on October .Chancellor Rishi SunakWhat does this mean for employers From this date, employers will be required to start contributing more eachmonth.They will also have to start paying National Insurance Contributions and pension contributions for the hours the employee is on furlough.From September , employers will be made to contribute % towards the wage payments ndash which will be added on to % provided by the UK Government.And From October , employers will have to contribute %, added on to % by the UK Government.Full details can be found here.What does this mean for furloughed staff The good news for you is that your wages will remain the same.You will continue to receive % of your salary ndash but the dference is just the adjustment of what your employer pays, and what the state pays.How many people are furloughed in Scotland According to figures published on July , nearly , people in Scotland have been helped by the furlough and self-employment support schemes.UK government figures show that, up to the end of June, , Scots had been furloughed.In addition, another , claims have been made to the scheme supporting self-employed workers during the lockdown period.What is the new timetable Here is the new furlough timetable, as set out by the UK Government:What do the experts say Martin Lewis at the MoneySavingExpert websitesays there could be ldquoserious consequence of this timetable.He said: ldquoIf your employer doesnt believe your role will be viable,it needs to start paying for it, theres a chance that this escalation of employment costs for the employer could tip it over the edge in seeking it to make employees redundant.ldquoWe hope this wont happen, but there is a chance.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-rename-bar-legend-volunteer
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers have re-named the bar in their clubrooms after volunteer Alan Allison.The new signs unveiling took place in the clubrooms on Sunday for his th birthday.For almost a decade Alan has manned the bar voluntarily every weekend serving refreshments to members and visitors.Apart from the current pandemic which forced the closure of the bar from March, he has only missed one sht ndash a Saturday in May  when he was at Hampden to see Hibernian lt the Scottish Cup.Gala Fairydean Rovers chairman Ryan Cass said:"Alan is a legend at the club and no-one deserves this more than him."With his th birthday coming up this week, we felt it was appropriate to re-name the bar in his honour."The Alan Allison bar reopened last weekend.Meanwhile on the playing front Gala Fairydean Rovers first team resume training this weekend so they will be fully prepared for the new Lowland League campaign which is expected to get underway at the start of October.

title: earlier-lockdown-saved-lives-london-bus-drivers-study-suggests
story: An earlier lockdown could have saved the lives of London bus drivers who died during the Covid- pandemic, according to an independent review.Many of the drivers who died had underlying health conditions and it is likely the frontline nature of their jobs added to their greater risk of death, the review by the UCL Institute of Health Equity found.London bus drivers aged - had a mortality rate that was . times higher than men of the same age in all occupations in England and Wales from March to May.Professor Sir Michael Marmot, the director of the UCL Institute of Health Equity, said that ldquobecause London was an early centre of the pandemic, it is likely that the increased risk among London bus drivers is associated with exposure.vw,vw,px, px"A bus is deep cleaned He added: ldquoOur review explicitly suggests that lockdown was the main factor that saved bus driversrsquo lives.ldquoIf lockdown had occurred earlier, it would likely have saved more lives.ldquoFor those with high blood pressure, exposure to Covid- is particularly hazardous, disproportionately affecting drivers of ethnic minority backgrounds.ldquoIn addition to reducing exposure to the virus, all drivers should therefore be screened for health risk, with those most vulnerable to dying from the virus receiving the most benefit.Transport for Londoncommissioned the review after  of its bus drivers were reported to have died with Covid-.The study focused on the deaths of  of those drivers, as one had been on sick leave for other reasons before February , and another death occurred in June .Among those who died, most stopped work in the  days either side of the March  lockdown, which suggests they became infected before it was imposed.Death rates among drivers came down after the lockdown was imposed, which reinforces evidence that it was an effective measure in saving lives, the review found.Of the  death certicates provided by relatives to the review, high blood pressure was identied as a contributory factor to the driverrsquos death in seven cases.vw,vw,px, px"Wearing a face covering is mandatory for passengers on public transport in England Cardiovascular disease, links between the sedentary nature of bus driving with heart disease and high blood pressure has been a known health risk in the profession since the s and s.The review found that a high proportion of drivers who died lived in the quarter of London boroughs with the highest Covid- death rates in April , and they were black or from ethnic minority communities, which are at more risk of becoming severely ill and dying from the virus.Lilli Matson, TfLrsquos chief safety, health and environment officer, said the company has been ldquodevastated by the tragic deaths of our colleagues and it commissioned the study to try to find ways to cut the risk of others contracting coronavirus.She said: ldquoIt is clear from this piece of work and others that there are certain characteristics that make people more vulnerable to coronavirus.ldquoWe will work with our bus operators to ensure that they consistently carry out risk assessments and appropriate support is given to those that need it.ldquoWe know that those with underlying health conditions, such as hypertension and cardiovascular disease, are at higher risk.London mayor Sadiq Khan said: ldquoThe results of the study show that a range of factors contributed to the tragic deaths, including the Governmentrsquos decision on when to go into lockdown, underlying health conditions, ethnicity and where they lived.ldquoI am determined to do all I can to protect staff by putting into practice the recommendations made ndash building on the actions we have already taken to enhance cleaning, reduce interaction with passengers, and limit capacity.ldquoThis will include proper guidance for bus operators, risk assessments for staff and access to dedicated health advice and support.TfL said it is extending its wellbeing initiatives and will work with bus operators to prepare a response plan to help us make ldquoimmediate, consistent interventions in the event of further outbreaks, she added.Enhanced daily cleaning using hospital-grade disinfectant in the driversrsquo cabs, the parts of the bus regularly touched by passengers, and in staff facilities, are among the safety measures which have been imposed.The seats nearest the driver are now out of use and the holes in the partition separating them have been blocked up.Passengers have also previously been made to board through the middle doors so they are not standing next to drivers.The study was set up to look at what measures are working and where improvements could be made. Recommendations for any additional health measures will be considered in stage two of the review..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Earlier lockdown could have saved lives of London bus drivers, study suggests

title: owners-infect-pet-cat-covid-19-uk
story: A pet cat has fallen ill with coronavirus in the UK after apparently catching Covid- from its owners.The infection was confirmed following tests at the Animal and Plant Health Agencylaboratory in Weybridge, Surrey, on July .Yvonne Doyle, medical director at Public Health England , said: ldquoThis is the first case of a domestic cat testing positive for Covid- in the UK but should not be a cause for alarm.ldquoThe investigation into this case suggests that the infection was spread from humans to animal, and not the other way round.ldquoAt this time, there is no evidence that pets can transmit the disease to humans.ldquoIn line with the general advice on fighting coronavirus, you should wash your hands regularly, including before and after contact with animals.A private vet initially diagnosed the pet with feline herpes virus, a common cat respiratory infection, but the sample was also tested for Covid- part of a research programme.The case has been reported to the World Organisation for Animal Health in line with international agreements.There have been a small number of confirmed cases in pets in other countries in Europe, North America and Asia.The UKrsquos chief veterinary officer, Christine Middlemiss, said: ldquoTests conducted by the Animal and Plant Health Agency have confirmed that the virus responsible for Covid- has been detected in a pet cat in England.ldquoThis is a very rare event, with infected animals detected to date only showing mild clinical signs and recovering within a few days.ldquoThere is no evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans.ldquoWe will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change.A team of scientists at the University of Glasgow Centre for Virus Research are behind the programme to screen hundreds of samples for Covid- infections in the UK cat population.Researchers at the CVR have now completed a full genome sequencing of the virus found in the infected cat.Professor Margaret Hosie, who works on the project, said: ldquoThere have been sporadic reports of cats from Covid- households in Hong Kong, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Spain and the US that tested positive forand were presumed to be infected from their owners, but this is the first report of an infected cat in the UK.ldquoAll available evidence suggests that the cat was infected from its owners, who had previously tested positive.ldquoThe cat and its owners have since made a full recovery and there was no transmission of the virus to other animals or people in the household.Professor William Weir of the University of Glasgowrsquos School of Veterinary Medicine, said: ldquoThe factors that govern why one species is susceptible to the Covid- virus while others are more resistant are currently unknown, but will likely reveal more about how this virus spreads and causes disease.ldquoAt present, there is no evidence that cats, dogs or other domestic animals play any role in the epidemiology of human infections with .He said cats and dogs with reported infections usually recover and there has been no evidence of transmission occurring between cats or dogs..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Owners  uinfect pet cat u with Covid- in the UK

title: lawyers-wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-kept-dark-new-indictment
story: Lawyers acting for WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange said they were ldquokept in the dark over a new indictment drawn up by US authorities, a court has heard.The indictment, published by the US Department of Justice last month, includes fresh allegations which US prosecutors said show how Assange sought to obtain and release classied information.Assange, , still faces  charges under the Espionage Act and conspiracy to commit computer intrusion and no additional charges have been added.US prosecutors now allege Assange sought to recruit hackers at conferences and also of conspiring with the leader of hacking group LulzSec and asking to be provided with documents and databases.The details of the new indictment have yet to be served as part of his extradition hearing, and prosecutor Joel Smith told Westminster Magistratesrsquo Court he was unable to ldquocommit to any timetable for its presentation.The full hearing, originally set for May, was postponed as a result of lockdown measures introduced to tackle the coronavirus pandemic and will take place on September  at the Old Bailey.District judge Vanessa Baraitser set another administrative hearing for August .vw,vw,px, px"WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange The move to alter the allegations has been criticised by supporters of Assange, who say that it will delay the trial further.Edward Fitzgerald, representing Assange, told the court the defence had been ldquokept in the dark about the new charges.ldquoThis is the first time that the US has indicated that they intend to bring a fresh request, he said.ldquo the new request we have been kept in the dark about it.
